title-group.article-title: Occurrence of two species of Bursaphelenchus (Nematoda: Aphelenchoididae) in the reproductive organs of Monochamus saltuarius (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)
title-group.alt-title: Occurrence of two species of Bursaphelenchus (Nematoda: Aphelenchoididae) in the reproductive organs of Monochamus saltuarius (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)

abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: To clarify the species composition and residency of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the bodies of Monochamus saltuarius adults, we dissected 70 adults that had emerged from cut pine bolts set at two locations at the frontline of pine wilt disease spread in Nagano Prefecture, Japan. Fourth-stage dispersal juveniles of Bursaphelenchus nematodes were detected in 39 insects; PCR-based identification showed that the insects mainly harboured B. mucronatus, but could sometimes harbour B. xylophilus or both. Detailed dissection of 17 insects revealed that hundreds of Bursaphelenchus nematodes were often found in the reproductive organs of both sexes, including the inner parts such as the internal sac and the ejaculatory ducts in males. Thus, the residence of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the reproductive organs of their vectors is not an accidental invasion but indicative of the phoretic nature of the nematodes.

body.p: The pine wood nematode, Bursaphelenchus xylophilus (Steiner & Buhrer) Nickle, is the causal agent of pine wilt disease (Kiyohara & Tokushige, 1971; Mamiya, 1983) and has caused heavy damage to pine forests in East Asia and Europe by its strong virulence (Futai, 2013). Bursaphelenchus xylophilus is native to North America (Dwinell & Nickle, 1989) and Pinus trees distributed in the eastern part of the North American continent are resistant (Kiyohara & Tokushige, 1971; Futai & Furuno, 1979). By contrast, B. mucronatus Mamiya & Enda, a species closely related to B. xylophilus (Mamiya & Enda, 1979), is widely distributed in the Eurasian continent (Braasch et al., 2011) and shows almost no virulence to Pinus trees (Braasch, 2000; Kanzaki & Futai, 2006; Kanzaki et al., 2012). Both B. xylophilus and B. mucronatus are known to be vectored by cerambycid beetles of the genus Monochamus (Akbulut & Stamps, 2012).

There are two ways of transmission by which Bursaphelenchus nematodes, harboured by their Monochamus vector, enter pine trees. One is via feeding wounds made by Monochamus adults on healthy pine twigs (Mamiya & Enda, 1972; Morimoto & Iwasaki, 1972; Linit, 1990; Jikumaru & Togashi, 2001), and the other is via oviposition wounds along with the oviposition behaviour of female adults on declining or recently killed pine trees (Wingfield, 1983; Wingfield & Blanchette, 1983; Linit, 1988; Schroeder & Magnusson, 1992; Ishiguro & Aikawa, 2016). The latter pathway could be of critical importance for the maintenance of the nematode population, especially when they are not virulent to the trees, because such avirulent nematodes transmitted via beetle feeding wounds would not be able to overcome resistance from healthy pine trees and fail to establish.

Bursaphelenchus nematodes infesting a dead host tree transfer to the body of a Monochamus beetle when the beetle ecloses to an adult in the pupal chamber (Maehara & Futai, 2001) and are carried with the insect following the emergence of the adult beetle (Kobayashi et al., 1984; Linit, 1988; Aikawa, 2008). When carried by an adult beetle, Bursaphelenchus nematodes are mainly held in the respiratory system (Kobayashi et al., 1984; Linit, 1988; Aikawa, 2008; Naves et al., 2015). On the other hand, Arakawa & Togashi (2004) showed that B. xylophilus invades the reproductive system of female adults of M. alternatus Hope in an experiment in which they demonstrated the transfer of nematodes between paired male and female beetles reared in plastic containers. It would be advantageous for Bursaphelenchus nematodes to stay in the reproductive organs of the Monochamus vectors as the transmission pathway via the oviposition scar is potentially critical for the survival of the nematodes, especially when they are not virulent to host trees, and the nematodes harboured in and around the reproductive organs are likely to be involved in such a transmission. However, the distribution of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the reproductive organs of Monochamus beetles has not been well explored and information is scarce.

In Japan, B. xylophilus is almost exclusively vectored by M. alternatus (Mamiya & Enda, 1972; Morimoto & Iwasaki, 1972). The congeneric species, M. saltuarius (Gebler), exhibits segregated distribution in high-altitude pine forests (Iwata, 1992) and is often associated with B. mucronatus (Jikumaru & Togashi, 1995, 2001). Monochamus saltuarius, however, is also known to carry B. xylophilus when pine wilt disease becomes prevalent in their habitat (Yoshida & Kondo, 1991; Taketsune, 1992; Shin, 2008). This study was done to investigate the species composition of Bursaphelenchus nematodes carried by M. saltuarius in areas where pine wilt disease is spreading into this habitat and to elucidate the transport locations of nematodes in the beetle vector. We confirmed that Bursaphelenchus nematodes were frequently found in the reproductive organs of M. saltuarius under field conditions. Further, we report the detection of the simultaneous occurrence of B. xylophilus and B. mucronatus in M. saltuarius adults, which provides evidence for the invasion process of B. xylophilus that is currently underway.

sec.title: Origin of the insects
sec.p: We used M. saltuarius adults that had emerged from bait logs set at two locations of Pinus densiflora Sieb. & Zucc. stands in high-altitude forests in Nagano Prefecture, Japan; one stand is in Sakuho Town (980 m a.s.l.) and the other in Matsumoto City (945 m a.s.1.). These stands were located at the frontline of pine wilt disease spread in Nagano Prefecture. No pine wilt damage was found around the stands, whereas substantial damage was present in the adjacent low-altitude areas.

For both stands, bait logs were prepared by cutting live P. densiflora trees of about 20 cm DBH (diam. at breast height) into bolts, approximately 1 m long, just before setting. The bolts were sealed with a commercial caulking compound (Silicone Sealant 8060 PRO, SR066, Cemedine Co., Ltd) at the cut ends to prevent drying. Three sets of bolts, ca 0.1 m3 vol, were placed on the ground with a distance of 100 m at the edge of each stand, on 22 and 23 May 2017, in Matsumoto and Sakuho, respectively. Monochamus beetles are strongly attracted to the volatiles emitted by weakened or newly killed pine trees (Ikeda et al., 1980, 1986; Yamasaki et al., 1980; Allison et al., 2001) and therefore bolts of freshly felled pine trees are often used as bait to attract and serve as oviposition sites for Monochamus beetles (Wingfield, 1983; Aikawa et al., 2020).

The bolts were left in the field for approximately 2 months and then transported to the Nagano Prefecture Forest Research Center, Shiojiri, Nagano, Japan. Bolts from both stands were placed separately in outdoor cages. The cages were checked for newly emerged Monochamus adults from the bolts every 2 or 3 days from May-July 2018. A total of 90 adults of M. saltuarius – 45 from Sakuho and 45 from Matsumoto – were collected from 17 May to 12 June; ten M. alternatus adults emerged from the Matsumoto logs. A total of 70 (40 males and 30 females) out of the 90 M. saltuarius adults were transported to Tohoku Research Center of Forestry and Forest Products Research Institute, Morioka, Iwate, Japan – 35 adults from Sakuho (25 males and ten females) and 35 adults from Matsumoto (15 males and 20 females). These insects were individually placed into plastic cups (72 mm high, 38 mm diam.) and kept at 5°C in the dark until dissected.

sec.title: Distribution of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the insect body
sec.p: To clarify the presence and distribution of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the body of the M. saltuarius adult, all 70 insects were dissected and checked for nematodes in various parts of the insect body.

caption.p: Reproductive organs of male and female Monochamus saltuarius. A: Male; B: Female.

sec.p: Each insect was measured for elytron length and fresh weight using an electronic calliper and a precision balance, respectively. The insect was individually placed on a Syracuse watch glass and dissected under a stereo microscope in accordance with the following procedure. Elytra and hind wings were cut from the body. The exposed dorsal surface of the abdomen was washed with distilled water to distinguish between nematodes on the body surface and those harboured in the tracheal system and internal organs. The main part of the insect was then transferred to a different watch glass. The membrane of the abdominal tergum was cut to check for the presence of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the haemocoel and the reproductive organs were excised, rinsed with distilled water and moved to another watch glass where they were dissected using tweezers to confirm the presence of the nematodes. As the inspection of the dissected insects progressed, it became clearer that Bursaphelenchus nematodes commonly occurred in the reproductive organs of the insects; thus we added a detailed dissection of the organs as described in the following section, this being applied to the remaining 17 insects. The remaining part of the insect body was carefully shredded using tweezers and checked for the presence of nematodes in the intestinal organs and tracheal system.

The contents of three watch glasses per insect were placed together in a Baermann funnel (Hooper, 1986) and kept overnight to extract the nematodes. The harvested nematodes were observed under a stereo microscope (8-100×) and Bursaphelenchus nematodes were counted. When the nematodes were too abundant to count, the nematode suspension was diluted and the total number of nematodes was estimated.

sec.title: Distribution of nematodes in reproductive organs
sec.p: In the dissection procedure described in the previous section, an additional detailed inspection of the reproductive organs was conducted using 17 insects. The reproductive organs excised from each insect were divided into (groups of) organs as follows and individually dissected to reveal and count the nematodes within.

Male reproductive organs were separated into three groups (Fig. 1A): median lobe combined with tegmen, internal sac, and ejaculatory ducts. The internal sac is a membranous structure from the median orifice to the ejaculatory ducts. Ejaculatory ducts are a pair of tubes derived from the testes. Female reproductive organs were separated into five, as follows (Fig. 1B): coxite, paraproct, vagina, bursa copulatrix, and spermatheca. The coxite and paraproct are separated by the valvifer. The vagina is a membranous structure, excluding the bursa copulatrix and spermatheca, in the region behind the paraproct. The morphology of the reproductive organs was identified with reference to Saito & Saito (1992).

sec.title: Molecular identification of the nematode from the insects
sec.p: Molecular identification of Bursaphelenchus nematodes isolated from insects is necessary as it is impossible to discriminate among species depending on the morphology of fourth-stage dispersal juveniles carried by the vectors. Identification of the nematode species was performed by species-specific PCR primer pairs.

Nematode DNA was prepared from ten nematodes arbitrarily picked from the nematode suspensions extracted from the insects by the Baermann method mentioned above. After the nematodes were lysed by incubation at 55°C for 1 h in 30 μl of extraction buffer, supplied with the B. xylophilus detection kit (Nippon Gene), the lysate was incubated from 95-100°C for 10 min.

Species-specific primer pairs for B. mucronatus and B. xylophilus, described by Matsunaga & Togashi (2004), were used for nematode identification. PCR amplification was performed in a total volume of 22 μl: 2 μl of extracted DNA solution, 10 pmol of each primer pair for the two species, and 10 μl of GoTaq® G2 Hot Start Green Master Mix, 2× (Promega). GoTaq® G2 Hot Start Green Master Mix is a premixed ready-to-use solution containing GoTaq® G2 Hot Start Polymerase, dNTPs and MgCl2. PCR amplification was performed under the following conditions: initial denaturation at 95°C for 2 min, 35 cycles of denaturation at 94°C for 30 s, annealing at 55.9°C for 30 s, and extension at 72°C for 1 min, followed by a final incubation at 72°C for 2 min. The PCR products were resolved by electrophoresis in a 1% agarose gel using 0.5× TAE buffer at pH 8.0 and stained with ethidium bromide. The band pattern was photographed under UV light.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Elytron length and fresh weight of M. saltuarius adults were compared by two-way ANOVA by sex and stand of origin. The ratio of insects carrying Bursaphelenchus nematodes to those not carrying the nematodes in the Sakuho and Matsumoto populations, and in males and females in both populations, were compared according to Fisher’s exact test. The number of nematodes extracted from the insects showed a wide variation; therefore, the Kruskal-Wallis test was used for evaluating differences in nematode load between different sexes and stands of different origin. The relationship between the number of nematodes found in the reproductive organs of M. saltuarius adults used in the detailed examination and the total number of nematodes harboured by the insects were analysed by Spearman’s rank correlation. All statistical analyses were performed by R statistical software (ver. 3.6.1).

caption.p: Number of dissected adults of Monochamus saltuarius and their body size.

sec.title: Distribution of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the insect body
sec.p: Elytron length and fresh weight were larger in female insects than in males from both the Sakuho and Matsumoto stands, and were larger in Sakuho than in Matsumoto (Table 1). Two-way ANOVA showed a significant difference between the sexes ( F = 22.49, df = 1, P < 0.001 for elytron length; F = 5.95, df = 1, P < 0.05 for fresh weight) and between stands ( F = 11.50, df = 1, P < 0.01 for elytron length; F = 11.73, df = 1, P < 0.01 for fresh weight), but not for the interaction ( F = 0.23, df = 1, P = 0.64 for elytron length; F = 0.05, df = 1, P = 0.83 for fresh weight).

caption.p: Number of Bursaphelenchus nematodes isolated from the dissected adults of Monochamus saltuarius.

sec.p:
Bursaphelenchus nematodes were found in 16 out of 35 (45.7%) and 23 out of 35 (65.7%) insects from Sakuho and Matsumoto, respectively. The percentage of insects carrying Bursaphelenchus nematodes was significantly different between males and females in Sakuho (Fisher’s exact test, P = 0.022), but there was no significant difference either in Matsumoto or between the stands (Fisher’s exact test, P > 0.05) (Table 2). The mean number of Bursaphelenchus nematodes carried by the insects was 3728 ± 8502 and 659 ± 1588 in Sakuho and Matsumoto, respectively (Table 2). The Kruskal-Wallis test showed that the difference in the number of nematodes carried by males and females was significant in Sakuho (
χ
2
= 4.98, df = 1, P = 0.03), but this difference was not significant either in Matsumoto (
χ
2
= 1.54, df = 1, P = 0.21) or between the stands (
χ
2
= 0.0003, df = 1, P = 0.99) (Table 2). For the Sakuho population, a higher percentage of females carried certain numbers of Bursaphelenchus nematodes, whereas some males carried extremely high numbers (11 150-40 550). This caused a statistical difference between males and females in the Kruskal-Wallis test, despite the small difference in the mean number of nematodes carried by the insects (Table 2).

Bursaphelenchus nematodes isolated from the insects of the two stands were identified as fourth-stage dispersal juveniles by morphological observations under a stereo microscope. The nematodes were mostly found in the tracheal system of the insect body; however, several were found inside the reproductive organ(s). Not one Bursaphelenchus nematode was found in the haemocoel and intestinal organs.

sec.title: Distribution of nematodes in reproductive organs
sec.p: A detailed examination of the reproductive organs showed clear evidence of the presence of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in those organs of the vector insects (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the reproductive organs of both sexes of Monochamus saltuarius. A: Bursaphelenchus nematodes in internal sac of a male insect (oval); B: Bursaphelenchus nematode in ejaculatory duct of a male insect (arrows); C: Bursaphelenchus nematodes packed in vagina of a female insect (circle); D: Bursaphelenchus nematodes released from cut wall of spermatheca of a female insect.
Bursaphelenchus nematodes carried in the reproductive organs of the insects from detailed examination of 17 Monochamus saltuarius adults.

sec.p: Twelve out of 17 insects used in the detailed examinations carried Bursaphelenchus nematodes and a proportion of those nematodes were harboured in the reproductive organs of the insect except for a female (♀-2) having no nematodes in its reproductive organs (Table 3). In male insects, Bursaphelenchus nematodes were found in the median lobe combined with the tegmen, internal sac, and ejaculatory ducts (Fig. 2A, B). In most cases, the number of nematodes found in the organs was more than 100, and this was also true when we focused on the inner parts, like the internal sac and ejaculatory ducts. Two female insects were found to carry Bursaphelenchus nematodes in their reproductive organs. One (♀-3) held 183 nematodes in the vagina (Vag) (Fig. 2C), 54 in the spermatheca (St) (Fig. 2D), and small numbers in the coxite (Cx) and paraproct (Pp). In the other (♀-4), nematodes were only found in the spermatheca and totalled 56. The frequency, number, and distribution of the Bursaphelenchus nematodes found in the insect’s reproductive organs was unlikely to have resulted from an accidental invasion of the nematodes.

The number of nematodes found in the reproductive organs accounted for 0.0-75.7% of the total number of nematodes isolated from the insects (Table 3). There was no significant correlation between the number of nematodes from the reproductive organs and the total number of nematodes (Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient,
r
s
= 0.53, P = 0.07) (Fig. 3).

caption.p: Relationship between number of nematodes found in the reproductive organs of Monochamus saltuarius adults used in the detailed examination and the total number of nematodes harboured by the insects. Black circles represent the Sakuho insect population; white triangles the Matsumoto insect population.

sec.title: Molecular identification of the nematode from the insects
sec.p: PCR amplification with the two primer pairs produced species-specific DNA fragments for each of the two Bursaphelenchus species, B. mucronatus and B. xylophilus. The nematode species detected in the insects were shown in Table 4. All 15 insects from Sakuho were proven to harbour only B. mucronatus, no B. xylophilus being detected. By contrast, B. xylophilus was detected in ten out of 23 insects from Matsumoto, three of which also harboured B. mucronatus, although 13 insects harboured B. mucronatus only (Table 4).

caption.p: Identification of Bursaphelenchus nematodes isolated from adults of Monochamus saltuarius by PCR.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Most nematode species belonging to the Bursaphelenchus have a phoretic relationship with insects (Ryss et al., 2005; Kanzaki & Giblin-Davis, 2018) and are found in various parts of the bodies of the vector insects, including the reproductive organs (Giblin et al., 1981; Giblin & Kaya, 1983; Giblin, 1985; Giblin-Davis et al., 2006; Cardoza et al., 2006; Kanzaki et al., 2008, 2010; Tanaka et al., 2014; Tomalak & Filipiak, 2019). Among them, the B. xylophilus group (Braasch et al., 2009) are known to be held exclusively in the tracheae of their Monochamus vectors (Kobayashi et al., 1984; Linit, 1988; Aikawa, 2008; Naves et al., 2015). In the present study, we revealed that nematodes of the B. xylophilus group are also harboured in the reproductive organs of both sexes of M. saltuarius.

There were some differences in body size (Table 1) and nematode load (Table 2) of the M. saltuarius adults used in this study, depending on the sex or the stand of origin, which might be due to the condition of the pine logs used for oviposition and rearing of the insects and the environmental factors of the site where the logs were set. Despite the differences in body size and nematode load, Bursaphelenchus nematodes were commonly found in the reproductive organs of the insects examined.

The invasion of B. xylophilus into the spermathecae of M. alternatus females along with copulation under laboratory conditions was reported by Arakawa & Togashi (2004). In their study, however, the location of the nematodes in the female reproductive organs, apart from the spermathecae, and in the male insects was not clarified. In this study, we demonstrated that Bursaphelenchus nematodes were commonly found in the reproductive organs of both male and female adults of M. saltuarius (Table 3). These adults had not copulated as they were captured just after emergence; thus, our results indicate that nematode invasion into the reproductive organs can occur without copulation. These results suggest that Bursaphelenchus nematodes vectored by Monochamus beetles utilise the reproductive organs as one of the phoretic transport sites.

Residence in the reproductive organs of the female insects would be beneficial for Bursaphelenchus nematodes that need to be transferred to a dead tree as a new habitat as the insect’s oviposition in such a tree would facilitate their transmission. Nematodes held at and around the genitalia of male insects would have a high chance of transferring to the female genitalia during copulation and then reaching host trees during subsequent oviposition. Thus, we consider that the invasion of the reproductive organs of the vector insects could represent part of the phoretic ecology of Bursaphelenchus nematodes. On the other hand, the occurrence of Bursaphelenchus nematodes in the reproductive organs can be a burden on the reproductive performance of the vector insects (Arakawa & Togashi, 2004).

Monochamus saltuarius mainly associates with B. mucronatus in Japan, but can also be a vector of B. xylophilus (Kishi, 1995; Sato et al., 1987). The molecular identification of the nematodes isolated from M. saltuarius adults in the present study showed that the insects from Sakuho had only B. mucronatus, whereas insects from Matsumoto had both B. mucronatus and B. xylophilus. In three insects from Matsumoto we confirmed that B. mucronatus and B. xylophilus occurred together in the nematode assemblage originating from a single insect. To our knowledge, this is the first report of both B. mucronatus and B. xylophilus being isolated from a single vector insect in the field. Pine wilt disease is becoming prevalent in Nagano Prefecture, which means that the B. xylophilus-M. alternatus association is penetrating into the area where the B. mucronatus-M. saltuarius association has been distributed. The disease expansion was quicker in Matsumoto than in Sakuho, thus the bait logs set at the stand in Matsumoto could attract M. alternatus carrying B. xylophilus, as well as M. saltuarius carrying B. mucronatus and be inhabited by both nematode species transmitted via the oviposition of the beetles. As a consequence, both nematode species could take passage in some of the M. saltuarius adults eclosed in the log and then emerge, as suggested by Yanagisawa et al. (2019).

In this study, we identified two Bursaphelenchus species, i.e., B. mucronatus and B. xylophilus, from M. saltuarius adults (Table 4); however, we did not closely examine the nematode species in the reproductive organs of the insects (Table 3). Further studies are needed to reveal the ways in which B. mucronatus and B. xylophilus enter the reproductive organs of M. saltuarius and M. alternatus so as to clarify the invasion process of the B. xylophilus-M. alternatus association into an area where the B. mucronatus-M. saltuarius association has been established.
